print_settings.Notes:: The roller itself is printed on its end and covered in a web of supports. Set supports on as fine definition as you can and tune the inflation distance settings so that all the supports are connected, but not completely covering the dots. Fun fact: There are 240 little dots, and you will be removing supports from each and every one of them. If your settings are good, the supports should come off like the shell of a properly hard-boiled egg. If not, well, good luck; get out your needle-nose pliers. I strongly recommend 3 shells for this one to make the dots nice and strong.

title: SLA Platform Roller
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Roller for 3DSystems ProJet series SLA build platforms. Will also work on any platform with the same hexagonal pattern of 1/4" holes spaced 1/16" apart. I typically use it after platforms are cured when the stuck supports are extra crunchy so that they come out clean. It can be used after a scrub in alcohol to avoid stickiness, but the supports will usually be softer then.

Printed in 3D Solutech PLA on a 2016 Flashforge Creator Pro.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1mm - .25mm

Infill:

10% - 25%

Notes:

Print the crossbar on one of its ends with no supports and 3 shells, if time permits. The threadform inside is a 100 degree included angle which creates a 40 degree overhang, so the threads print well on most printers without any help.

Print two screws on their heads with optional supports in the slots. I used supports for cosmetic purposes, but most printers should be able to bridge it okay. The slots are 3mm so they should fit most car keys, coins, and other flat stuff you've got within arm's reach.

Print the handle on its top face (opposite the grip) with supports inside the bolt holes. At this point, you will probably notice my bolt holes are not filleted symmetrically. I don't know where I went wrong. This is fine. Ignore it if you can.

The roller itself is printed on its end and covered in a web of supports. Set supports on as fine definition as you can and tune the inflation distance settings so that all the supports are connected, but not completely covering the dots. Fun fact: There are 240 little dots, and you will be removing supports from each and every one of them. If your settings are good, the supports should come off like the shell of a properly hard-boiled egg. If not, well, good luck; get out your needle-nose pliers. I strongly recommend 3 shells for this one to make the dots nice and strong.

title: Boeing 737 Ceiling Flyer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
When strung up to the ceiling, the plane will "fly" in circles under the power of its propeller. If there's enough interest I may release other aircraft including some actual prop-jobs, maybe even twin-engine. Like it if you want more.

Watch it fly with short propeller, slower: https://youtu.be/3tPDYEYpzAM
Long propeller, faster / bigger loops: https://youtu.be/QQKlanOFjk4

Materials:
1) Motor + switch + battery case ($12 for a set of 5 each): http://a.co/elPTgfI
2) Steel rod ($7.87 for a set of 20), 50mm length: http://a.co/7UfjWzZ
[You do not need the rods if using the "Shaft and Prop", but I think the rods work better.]
3) M3 screws, 5-10mm x 2
4) Two AA batteries
5) Soldering iron, flux, solder
6) Transparent filament to suspend plane, ~100cm
7) Screws to mount axis to ceiling
8) Glue, either E6000 or cyanoacrylate.
9) Hot glue gun

A note on printing: The body + wings part should be printed upside-down and rotated 45 degrees to fit on a 20x20cm build plate. This model cannot be printed on a smaller build plate if you intend to install the motor and batteries.

Assembly
1) Insert engine in tail with wires facing up, then glue tail to lower fuselage.
2) Glue nose cone to lower fuselage.
3) Remove electrical hardware from battery compartments (spring and gromet) with wires intact. I found nippers to do this easily.
4) Hot glue gun the electrical hardware in place on the lower fuselage. Be careful not to cover the conducting parts that will contact the batteries.
5) Pass the red wire from the motor up through the fuselage, into the nose cone, and out the rectangular hole in the top of the nose.
6) Pass the red wire from the battery compartment into the nose cone and out the rectangular hole.
7) Solder the red wires, 1 to each terminal on the switch.
8) Solder the black wire at the back of the battery terminal to the motor black terminal.
9) Insert 2 AA batteries, then screw on the fuselage top.
10) Insert the 2mm steel rod into the coupler and push though hole in back of tail, onto the motor spindle. If using the "Shaft and Prop", you won't need the steel rod.
11) Push the propeller onto the back of the steel rod.
12) Hang from the ceiling axis, flip the switch, and go fly!

Thanks to Navy876 for the cool model.

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Any. I used 0.25mm.

Notes:

If using the "uniprop", I recommend printing it on its side, with supports.

description.text:
Fan guards were essential for my new Flsun i3 DIY 3D Printer. Could not find anything suitable so modelled my own. Incorporated the Brand name as the Printer has no identification at all.
One is for the Main Extruder fan and twin guards for the Main Controller fans.
They are 4 mm thick with a 1.25 recess to clear the fan blades.
The LH and RH guards are for the Mother board fans. They are designed to just clip into the unused mounting holes on the fans, without disassembling the installed fans.
There also have cut outs to clear the screws fixing the fans to the front plate on the Motherboard.

description.text:
Model of the Quincy Mine, in Hancock, Michigan. One of the most prolific copper mines in its day, the Quincy mine also housed the world's longest mine shaft (1.75 miles on a 55 degree incline) by the time it ceased copper production in 1945. During WWII, it was responsible for roughly 25% of the nation's copper.

Want to learn more?

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quincy_Mine
http://www.geo.mtu.edu/KeweenawGeoheritage/BlackLavas/Quincy.html

Better still, take a tour:

http://www.quincymine.com/

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Can be printed with or without supports or raft/brim.

Finishing touches

Can be files/painted to better represent how the mine looks today, but looks pretty cool printed in silver, gray, transparent, or glow-in-the-dark filament. The Quincy mine is often lit at night, making the use of GID filament a nice touch.

Given the limitations of Tinkercad, this model took a lot of trial-and-error, and was designed from various photographs taken at different angles, then scaled to fit the smaller bed of the Monoprice Select Mini.

author: Basmaalmahmoud

description.text: This is a carrrier that interfaces with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:237822 that holds the springs and bolts instead of the rubber hose, for those so inclined. The .stl may have some issues, every time I send it to netfabb it comes back with holes. Maybe someone with more skills and a better program than sketchup can fix it. But you get the idea. Bolt holes are 12.5mm apart and the aitripper itself does not need any modification. Note - updated by Highcooley to fix the slicing issues in the camshaft. See igf 'Cam 3rd Try " works. Kurt updated the camshaft , this time I think we have it .

I designed this so there was support for the cam base circle from one side, so print it   standing up with that on the lower side. The counterbores for the springs and the holes for the 3mm x 50mm bolts do not need any support if you print it standing on one end so the holes are horizontal.. Since it is under pressure all the time use a dense infill so it is strong. The idler arm that holds the 608ZZ bearing is the same as  the Airtripper , but I enhanced it a little by making the walls next to the slots taller so the cam carrier has more area to push against.

comments.text: I tried to clean up the model a little but every time I try to hollow out the top rectangle it seems to make things crazy. So I limited my changes to the buttresses that build up the cam base circle ( so it can be printed without support). This is titled "cam 3rd try"

I suggest you delete the other parts as it is confusing as to which one you're supposed to download ^^.

title: Filter adapter for smartphone telephoto lens

description.text:
A simple adapter to fit a 49mm neutral density filter to a smartphone telephoto lens I purchased online. The filter is variable, it has a 2ND to 400ND range. The fit was a little loose on the filter so I placed a small rubber band on the threads. The result is a nice, tight fit but I can still remove the filter if necessary. The adapter fits snugly on the telephoto lens, it was designed to fit the 36mm barrel of the lens, the socket is tapered from 37mm to 36mm.

The whole purpose of this is to photograph the August 21st, 2017 eclipse. If things work well I'll post some follow up photos.

UPDATE: While the filter adapter was close the sun was still significantly brighter then what I felt was safe for the lens of the camera. What I ended up using was a combination of filter and eclipse viewing glasses. The filter did make it easy to adjust the exposure level once I had the eclipse glasses aligned, Unfortunately it was difficult to get both in perfect alignment, I've uploaded the best picture I was able to capture. it was still far better watching it with a second pair.

title: E3D V6 40 mm fan duct with blower mount

description.text:
I draw this fan duct to allow the installation of original Anet A8 fans on an E3D v6 clone (22,4 mm diameter).

In my first attempt to install E3D v6 on original Anet A8 plate, I had troubles with clogged hotend due to bad dissipation.
To solve this problem I opted for an aluminium plate to hold the E3D v6, but I had to find a place where to attach the blower fan; also, I prefered to use the bigger 40 mm fan instead of using the 30 mm that came with the hotend.

I looked around on Thingiverse, but I wasn't able to find a 40 mm fan duct that matches my E3D v6 size (it's the smallest size clone), so I designed a new one using interesting tricks I saw in other Things (shape, zip tie holder, etc.).
I also added two mounts to hold the blower fan.

This is my first complex design, so it suffers for some issues due to inexperience with 3D printing (i.e. hex nuts seats are quite tight)

description.text:
These are the printed parts to make adjustable-height feet to attach to the ends of the 2040 horizontal extrusions of the base frame of a Robotdigg SCARA printer. The printer needs 3 of them. The other parts you need are need three M6x30mm socket cap head screws (or one M6x30 for the foot and two M6x20 to attach it to the extrusion), two M6 nuts and a M6 thread tapping tool.

Remove the end caps from the extrusions and use the tapping tool to thread the two central holes to the length of the fixing screws less 5mm, then secure the larger printed part to the extrusion using two screws. Also thread the central hole of the round foot, then screw a M6x30mm cap head screw into it from the bottom until it is tight. Put a nut on the protruding screw end, then insert this into the underside of the other printed part so that the nut fits in the nut trap. Add another nut on the top side to finish off.

See my blog entry at https://miscsolutions.wordpress.com/2017/08/09/testing-the-robotdigg-scara-arm-3d-printer/ for how to strengthen the base frame of the printer.

remixed_from.title: Anet A6 easy magnetic extruder access (fixed)

title: Quick connect extruder fan - ANET A6

description.text:
This is an upgrade to make the extruder fan quickly detachable/attachable. Instead of using magnets, this design uses 'hooks/clips' to lock tightly into place. This was originally designed to fit the ANET A6 without having to modify the stock screws that keep the extruder stepper motor in place. This design still utilizes the stock heat sink, and has space dedicated for airflow from the fan.

After market parts needed for installation:
4 - Countersink screws (1" in length) with nuts (used to attach the fan to the thinner quick connect plate).

NOTE: If you are looking for the Batman fan cover it can be found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2468811

description.text:
To further decorate envelopes I send out for my web shop, I designed this rubber stamp with my logo.

I know there's not much use for you to have my logo, which I won't include, but maybe someone could use the handle or just the idea. I'm especially loving how the fingerprinty lines came out! That's done using a concentric infill on the initial layer in Cura and also the reason why some of the lines are not that straight in the print. I printed it oriented the other way you would normally do to avoid overhangs, so I the to be stamped part was touching the build plate. This is to ensure a good printing stamp. Orienting it the other way (stamp design up) will result in an inferior stamp quality. And since the lines that didn't print so well aren't touching the material you're stamping on it doesn't really matter.

The handle fits a 30x30mm stamp. To a certain extend you can scale and stretch it to fit your needs.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini & Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The stamp itself is printed on the Monoprice Select Mini with Robin Reiter's flexible filament upgrade (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2029972 and https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2030554), using Recreus's FilaFlex Skin II filament (230°C nozzle, 50°C heat bed, 120% flow, 20mm/s).

The handle is printed in Das Filament brown PLA on the CR-10 (210°C nozzle, 50°C heat bed).

To get those cool fingerprint like lines, tell your slicer (I used Cura) to use concentric lines on the initial layer.

To make the stamp I took my logo, brought it into Illustrator and saved it as an SVG, imported it into Tinkercad and gave it some depth. Then I added a cylinder on top to connect all the floating parts. This made the print a bit messy, as the flexible filament has a harder time bridging, but it came out well enough to work. You might not even need to do this, depending on your design. The handle was a quick sketch-and-pull job in Fusion 360, just guessing and eyeballing a bit, but it worked fine as well.

From my great-grandmother I inherited two suitecases, much older than I am. I love these two suitcases im memory of familie's history.

title: OoiTY's Beefy Dual Fan Bushing X-Carriage No X-axis loss

description.text: Updated by this; http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:92028 As popular as the designs for X-carriages with 40mm fans between the rods are, they cause a loss of x-axis travel of at least 10mm per fan. With 20mm fans like I use, this means there'll be a total of a 40mm reduction. The goal for this design is to maximize the amount of X-axis travel while still having 2 fans. Also, uses Zipties to secure the bushings to the carriage, since I noticed that regular designs for bushing carriages crack around the bushings. This is designed for 16mm bronze bushings, I got mine from techpaladin. Modeled in Rhino, unfortunately for openscad fans. Feel free to modify the original files.

Attach carriage to x-axis, fasten with zipties, tighten belts, add fans.
Uses M3 screws to attach fans to carriage.

comments.text: Beautiful model! Do you run into any binding problems with the bushings in those ziptie holders?
comments.author: Pointedstick

comments.text: Thanks! The bushings were a little tight in the ziptie holders, but I didn't have any binding problems so far.

Two-colored tent nail, Luminous at night

This simple tent nail should not help stumbling over the tent cords. The lower part (Part 2) is printed from neon orange PLA and the upper part (Part 1) is printed from the night PLA. Finally, the two parts are put together and screwed with a M3 threaded rod. The cube is 25 x 25 x 25 mm large.

Zweifarbiger Zeltnagel, Nachts Leuchtend

Dieser einfache Zeltnagel soll dabei Helfen nicht über die Zeltschnüre zu Stolpern. Der untere Teil (Part 2) ist aus Neon Orangenem PLA Gedruckt und der Obere Teil (Part 1) wird aus Nachts Leuchtenden PLA gedruckt. Zum Schluss werden beide teile zusammen gesteckt und mit einer etwa 25cm Langen Gewindestange M3 verschraubt. Der Würfel ist 25 x 25 mm x 25 Groß.

description.text:
These are the parts we used in a childrenâ€™s workshop in Madrid a few weeks ago. The goal was to create a character with some body parts created on a 3D printer and other parts made by cutting foam sheets with a hot wire. We used conductive play-doh (courseweb.stthomas.edu/apthomas/SquishyCircuits/index.htm) to generate simple circuits to power LEDs representing eyes, ears, or noses in the robots heads. The LEDs are powered by coin cell 4.5V batteries that fit in the torso. More information on the workshop: parametricomutante.com/taller-frankenstein-i/
parametricomutante.com/taller-frankenstein-ii/
crearchitetturattivamente.blogspot.com.es/2012/05/frankensteint-fomentando-las-relaciones.html

Estas son las piezas que utilizamos para un taller infantil desarrollado en Madrid hace unas semanas. ConsistÃ­a en montar un personaje con unas partes del cuerpo (cabeza, torso y piernas) fabricadas con impresiÃ³n 3D y otras (brazos) cortadas con hilo caliente de planchas de espuma. Usamos plastilina conductiva ( http://courseweb.stthomas.edu/apthomas/SquishyCircuits/index.htm ) para generar circuitos sencillos que pudieran encender leds simulando ojos, orejas o narices en las cabezas de los robots. Estos leds son alimentados por pilas de petaca de 4,5 V que entran en las piezas del torso (body). Alguna informaciÃ³n mÃ¡s del taller:

http://crearchitetturattivamente.blogspot.com.es/2012/05/frankensteint-fomentando-las-relaciones.html

(This project is still in development, it is necessary to refine the design of some parts.)  
Print the parts and mix them up!  
You will need a 4.5V coin cell battery if you want to put the squishy circuit inside the robot.  
Some of the parts (top01, top02, top03, tetravote, trivote01, trivote02) have support material - simply cut it off once printing is complete.

Ever since I installed the original E3D v6 hot end with a bowden setup, I've been having terrible skipping in my extruder. Upon researching the issue, I've read all over the net that people seem to oil their filament to reduce the stickyness of the filament. This is especially true when printing PLA due to its sticky property. There are multiple oiler designs on Thingiverse, but I didn't like any of them. So, I designed my own.

Here is a full feature list:

  • Designed to be fitted on my Customized Bowden Extruder Mount With 1/8'' BSPT Thread, but should also fit on the original Customizable Bowden Extruder | Mount for ANET A8 & Others. Simply mirror it in your slicer if needed.
  • Add a drop or two of oil daily, depending on your extruder's performance. I found that sunflower frying oil works best due to the higher smoking point.
  • Doubles as a filter, useful for removing dust from your filament if you are printing in a dusty environment.
  • The design has enough spacing between the extruder and oiling chamber so that you can feel with your fingers whether the filament is oily enough.
  • Hopper-like design on top to minimize spillage when adding oil.
  • Easy access to the oiling sponge from the side using a removable cover.
  • Filament can be removed and inserted sideways through the same opening.

For mounting, use an M3x10 screw. The side cover is snap-in, designed with my printer's tolerances in mind, but will probably work with other printers as well. Let me know if you are having any issues.

I have also included the Blender files in case you want to edit it further.

description.text:
Adaptor to allow the mounting of a device with 100mm VESA mounting holes (such as an Intel NUC PC) onto the back of a TV with 200 mm VESA mounting holes.

Some sites with info on VESA mounts:

  • Wikipedia Flat_Display_Mounting_Interface
  • Kanto Mounts
  • One for All.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:
  • I sliced with Cura 2.6.1.
  • Just fits on a standard reprap 200x200mm buildplate if you rotate it by 45 degrees and set the translation back to 0.
  • I printed in PLA with 1.2mm walls and 30% infill, and it seems quite sturdy.
  • The nut-traps theoretically need supports, but I printed without supports since I wasn't sure I'd be able to remove them. Was slightly messy, but worked.
  • The nut-traps are quite sensitive to tolerances (if they're too small the nuts won't go in). You can change their horizontal dimensions in FreeCAD by editing the 4.35mm constraint in Sketch002 (find it in the tree).
  • If you need to increase the height of the nut trap edit the length of the Sketch002 pad.

Hardware required
  • 2x 20mm M6 screws/bolts (for mounting to TV/Monitor), washers optional
  • 4x m4 nuts
  • 4x 8mm M4 scews if you lost the ones that came with your device. Bracket can acommodate up to around 12mm long screws.
Assembly
  • Clean up nut traps using needle nosed pliers or whatever you can find that fits inside.
  • Push m4 nuts into the nut traps. The sides of the nut should be paralel to the nut trap wall. You may need to push quite hard, I used needle nosed pliers.
  • If the nuts don't quite align with the holes you screw a longer m4 screw in a little and then lever the nut into place.

That's pretty much it, now you should be able to mount your device with the standard VESA hardware and attach the whole thing to the TV using the M6 bolts/screws.

Not a great FreeCAD model (I've not used it much), but you should be able to change the nut trap dimensions and the height of the nut-trap pads by changing a single number somewhere in the tree. If you dig a bit :)

  • If you want to experiment with the nut trap dimensions, intersect the model with the cube hidden in the tree, allowing you to print only that segment.
  • Note that you should probably do "refine shape" on the parametric shape and mesh the resulting refined shape each time you make a change.

This is a mid 1950's Chrysler Air Raid Siren, a part of YOUR Civil Defense! These HEMI powered machines used to be all over the country during the Cold War. I still remember the sound of them going off every Wednesday at noon for routine tests, and of course, during actual emergencies. I did not design this model, all I did was find it elsewhere some time ago and all I have done is split it into a couple of parts so I could print it. It is lacking many details, and isn't wholly accurate. As a model maker, these are issues I will fix post-printing, but to detail out the 3d model is still somewhat beyond me. At least until I figure out the software. Maybe one of you gurus can church this thing up in the meantime?

The 3mf files are what I came up with to print after splitting the original STL. I included them all. Please keep in mind that I'm NEW! I don't know what to do yet!

title: My Music Center Case Mod
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My Music Center is a popular child's toy piano, which can often be found on flee markets for about a $1. Due to its high availability it is fairly popular for circuit bending modification. You can find a lot of useful background information here: http://weltenschule.de/TableHooters/MyMusicCenter.html

Since it is a really cheap china-manufactured toy, the buttons are really shaky and to be honest, it's not exactly the most beautiful object. So I decided to pimp mine and printed new buttons, clamps and a new cover for the speaker.

The repository includes all openscad files, such that you can easily modify the print files, in particular, if you have a slightly different model.

Have fun!

Printer:

Stratasys Objet 30

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

as fine as possible

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I printed this when I had access to a professional Stratasys Objet 30 polyjet printer. However I would expect that it is printable on a Formlabs Form 2 or even any FDM printer that supports dissolvable support material.

Printing might be possible with a standard one-material FDM printer, but would likely require a lot of manual post-processing.

Grinding and Polishing

Since not all holes are equally sized some grinding and polishing is typically required to make the buttons fit perfectly.

title: Surround speaker stand for Ikea Poang chair
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I don't have any available space for my surround speakers, so I've designed a holder for the rear speakers that attaches to the Ikea Poäng chair.

Because the chair has a curve on the backside, there are two version of the stand, left and right. You should print one of each.

If you typically rock or move a lot in your chair, I suggest printing the clips as well. They should ensure that the stand won't come loose after time (happened to me twice).

Due to the large number of different speakers, there are no holes/mounting points. Use a drill at places appropriate for your speaker and attach with a small screw. If you're feeling lazy, Velcro or double-sided tape works fine. You could also take a small wood screw and drive it through the bottom side of the holder without pre-drilling any holes.

title: Extrusion multiplier calibration cube
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a 20mm x 20mm x 20mm cube with an open top and 0.8mm walls. I use it to calibrate the extrusion multiplier for my slicer for new spools. First set the multiplier to 1. Then change the extrusion width to Manual and set it to 0.4 (for 0.4mm nozzles) then print the cube. Measure the walls and take an average of all 4 sides. Then divide 0.8 by this value and you'll have your exact extrusion multiplier.

Printer:

D-Bot Core XY

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

Infill:

10%

Notes:

The infill percentage does not really matter. Set it to whatever you like but don't make it zero.

comments.author: Keshan

comments.text: On my D-Bot the extrusion width is set to the default 0.41 and I use the MKS Gen 1.4. The idea is to keep one parameter fixed and then vary just the extrusion multiplier to get the layer thickness right. If you have a 0.4 nozzle and are getting 1.0 thickness with 90% and 0.35 then I suspect the issue maybe with your nozzle itself and that its not 0.4 in reality. It could also be the firmware is corrupted somehow. More often than not I have re-flashed the firmware and all these annoying little issues disappeared. If you'd like I can share my PLA and PETG profiles for S3D.
comments.author: Keshan

comments.text: I'm guessing you are trying to print with PLA? When you first printed the cube was the multiplier set to 1? Also what is your default extrusion width set to? For e.g. my extrusion width is set to 0.41. This means that my wall thickness should be 0.82. So the formula = 0.82/whatever avg value you get. title: Pi-Pilot PVC Pipe Reamer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
When you need mythological salvation, look for a "sky pilot."

When you need salvation from a slightly-too-small inside diameter, look for a pi-pilot! (Pipe-pilot. Get it? Anyone?)

This is a guide to keep a spade bit from wandering and chattering while reaming a PVC pipe or fitting (or other soft material with an existing hole) to a larger size.

The included STL files may or may not work for you without adjustment. Your best bet would be to edit the .scad file and generate your own. If you need to fit something other than a 7/8-inch bit, you have no choice at the moment.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

You would be well-advised to take exact measurements of the spade bit you intend to use, as they vary in dimensions between manufacturers.

I was able to print this without supports so required cleanup was minimal. I did have to do some sanding due to poor printer calibration.

I included a "slop factor" of 1.25 since my Prusa i3 is long overdue for recalibration. If your printer is spot-on, you might be able to set the slop_factor value to 1.

Assembly is straightforward: Insert the bit into the guide body; snap the pilot section over the top, and start reaming!

When using this I found that a brand-new spade bit still tends to "grab" a bit, so be prepared for it. You might even try running the drill in reverse, although I have not. Drilling generates heat, and the PVC pipe will tend to soften. Lubricating with water while in use may be helpful though messy. The "results" photo is with an earlier iteration, but the principal is the same.

title: Laser Head Wire Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This mount provides a way to tie down the wires going to the laser and motor on the laser head.

Halfway through the first engraving I saw that the wires would soon break off, at the connectors, from all the movement.

It's designed for the widely available EleksLaser A3 Pro laser engraver kits (mid 2017), from online retailers; Banggood, GearBest, EleksMaker and eBay.

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

It can be printed from most any filament, I wouldn't recommend flexible.
It prints better with the nut side down (flipped over), and must have supports.
I recommend 3 layer side walls.

Installation

Unscrew the axle just enough to remove the nut. No need to remove the screw with wheel.
Place the nuts into the mount, slide into place, tighten screw.

The connectors will pass through the hole one at a time, just leave the connector close to the ring while pushing the second connector through. Zip-Tie wires to ring.

If made with ABS or PETg, you maybe able to slip the mount over the nuts without removing the them. Just be mindful not to crack off the sides.

The mount is not designed to hold the nut if you really want to torque it down. Use blue lock tight to secure.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
In my ongoing quest for affordable micro HD FPV, this quick prototype clean/dirty separated frame was created as a slightly more crash-proof smallest possible platform to mount a pi zero, WN722N wifi usb TX, naze32, and babyhawk/FT gremlin power train. This frame design is a super-rough prototype as I'm still chasing down vibrations that don't appear with analog FPV. Could just be the FC tuning.

There is no space for an R/C receiver since this requires none as the control signal transmits from a USB gamepad (or Taranis in USB mode) over the wifibroadcast link. You also do not need a separate OSD as the pi zero transmits the FC's telemetry down the link as well. To use this frame as intended, you will have to strip out all unnecessary weight/components off the wifi card and direct solder the usb/power connections, etc, including the antenna.

On my current flying prototype (not pictured), the lower frame/arms is actually 1.5mm fiberglass G10 for toughness but it is flyable if you print the lower frame STL file and try not to crash. ;-) Nylon or any other strong filament would be the best bet for that part

First shaky flights: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6SeZt63PmZI (post processing software + youtube = NOT actual video quality I see when flying)

Read about the super-awesome EZ-WifiBroadcast project on RCGroups: https://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?2664393-EZ-WifiBroadcast-cheap-digital-HD-transmission-made-easy!

MUCH thanks to Rodizio and everyone else contributing to the EZ-Wifibroadcast project. If I had more time I would contribute to it but I would probably just introduce bugs into the code and aircraft would fall from the sky in flaming wrecks :-)

Minimal Frame assembly requires:

  • 4x standoffs ~7mm

  • 4x Anti Vibration Dampers
    https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B073LPTHCL/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

  • 4x anti-vibration mounting grommets (between lower frame and mid-frame) https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B071RP443J/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

  • 4X 7mm rubber standoffs for the FC
    https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B07219Q2HX/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Notes on stuff that I was stuck on with EZWBC 1.5 -

For RC control, use CF 1.2.x branch since they removed MSP_RX in 2.x or roll your own CF with it enabled.

In CF, set UART baud at 57600 MSP Data (though EZWBC config is at 19200)

title: Traxxas TQi Link iPhone 5 / iPhone 6 Plus with OtterBox case Holder v2.0

description.text:
I really liked the features in the TraxxasLink app but now that the connection is done through bluetooth and not anymore with the cradle that was connecting AND holding the phone on the TQi remote, I had to come with something to hold my iPhone while I was driving my X-Maxx (I tried to order an optional third hand, but they were back order :) ).

So I designed this contraption that can be clamped to my Traxxas TQi without having to modify or damage the remote control itself.

The design is made to use 4-40 UNC Nuts and bolts (bolts are 1in long). If you want to prevent scratching your remote control, you can add some self-adhesive foam on the cylindrical parts that clamps on the remote control handle (I did put some, you can see it in the pictures).

The Phone clamp is designed to fit an iPhone 5 OtterBox Defender Case. But the way I designed this contraption, you can simply create your own phone clamp to fit with the other parts.

--------------Update 1--------------
I've added a new part for an iPhone 6 Plus, even though it's a kinda big phone to put on the top of a remote control.

--------------Update 2--------------
I've made some modification to the tightening ring (Part 06) so it will have more tightening force. I also added a new bracket system that will be easier to mount/unmount the device.

--------------Update 3--------------
Some holes were too tight.

description.text:
Had issued with Simplify3D slicing this. It was not flat along the ground plane and thus didn't make a skirt and tried to print it about 1 or 2 layers up. Oddly the skirt was only present around where the stem met the top of the bowl. Like it was just a fraction of a MM higher than the rest of the object. Also had a strange issue where the stem attaches to the bowl where there was space.

Ran a repair job on it then brought it into tinkerCAD. Shaved about .2mm off of the top of the bowl so that it would default to flat against the bed when I loaded the STL. Reloaded into S3D and made 4 copies for my feeders. Printed skirt around the 4 moats and print is going well now. Just remixing in case any S3D users out there are having trouble with this. Printing at .3mm now for speed, doesn't have to look great up close.

So many dead ants in the hummingbird feeders right now and I had to get it done!

comments.text:
I would make a new, longer support for the back, about 2" longer. You'll note you don't have the motor up against the wall in the picture, because you really have to have it out a bit anyway so the strain relief and cable from the heat bed don't hit the wall at maximum travel. The extra couple inches will but this back brace right around 12" out from the Z base, similar to the front braces, so there won't be a disadvantage in stiffness in using a rear brace. Then it would be basically perfect, same additional stiffness as front braces, no real extra clearance since it's needed for the heat bed anyway, and rear braces so they're not nearly as in the way as front braces.
The Z frame is roughly 2' high, so maximum stiffness would be 2' out, a 45 deg angle. The front is about 1' out so not bad, the rear is 8" out so considerably closer to vertical and less mechanical advantage to stiffen the Z frame. Your support already goes back a bit so about 10" and not bad really, but might as well use the other 2" or so of clearance that's required anyway, and bring it right in line with front stiffeners.

comments.text: Overall a great concept, the files work well but there are some issues I ran into. Honestly, don't bother with the two screwing pieces, go buy some 5/16 locking nylon nuts, they're gonna stay in place and stay in place WELL and also saves time/filament printing them. Second, the recommended 24 inch threaded rods are too small for the standard CR-10, get a 36 inch 5/16 rod, Home Depot if your impatient for shipping like me, and get them cut to about 26 inches. T-nuts are hard to find in-store, I recommend just printing six before you start, four of them you will have to trim down to fit in between the screws on the bottom of the printer like in the third picture. Also you'll need a small assortment of 3M screws to install, as stated below 25mm is too large, shoot for 15ish-mm, and you'll need two ~10 4M screws for the stock Z-axis T-nuts. Almost done installing now, I'll post a completed picture too.

comments.text: These are awesome! I put them on my CR-10, and the increase in stability is easily observable. My prints seem to be better, less shifting and ringing, though I haven't fully tested that. I think the main advantage here is that you might be able to print faster without distorting quality as much. Couple of things: two foot lengths of threaded rod is not long enough. I was able to mount them, but the rod doesn't go all the way through on both ends. The printed knobs with the threads did not fit either. Maybe they'd fit better on 8mm threaded rod(I used 5/6") but I'm not sure. I ended up using 5/16" nuts to secure the rods. Also, not sure what the rounded bits are for. Looks like they might be knobs to go over the nuts(there is a hexagonal recession underneath), but the nuts I had didn't fit, and the hole wasn't big enough to slip over the threaded rod anyway. Very easy to install anyway, and my machine vibrates a lot less.

remixed_from.author: ndupont
remixed_from.title: Tevo Tarantula 5mm idler spacer for Y axis

title: Tevo Tarantula Y axis motor rigidity spacers (3mm)

description.text:
Excellent rigidity, the lightweight way.

The Tevo Tarantula comes with 2 Y axis motor brackets, with only one being actually used.

With 4 sets of those spacers and 4 M3x35mm allen screws, the decorative bracket finally gets to serve the purpose it was designed for.

I found the screws on eBay, "M3*35mm A2 304 STAINLESS STEEL ALLEN BOLT"

  • Print 3 times the STL containing a pair of "pulley" spacers, a 9mm long middle strut, and a 2.5mm thick washer.
  • Print 1 single time the STL containing the thin-nosed pulley spacers and the plastic washer.
    All 4 are to be used with M3x35mm screws.

Print with 100% infill, with no brim or supports. Not too hot or you'll have to drill the 3mm holes after print.

Should the pulley be toast (stuck bearings), you can either sand off about 1mm from the dedicated spacers. Or print the additional STL containing a shorter spacer. The small play will prevent it to be locked.

Time lapse of 2 sets being printed : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w0jMCUMMwRQ

For the idle side (front of the machine), you'll find the 5mm spacers here : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2393545

Those spacers are also used in combination with the X-axis rigidity bracket : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2491596

description.text:
This is a construction set for building polyhedra and other surfaces. Each piece is a flat polyhedron that can join to any other piece along each edge.

Obviously you can print pieces as needed, but I recommend as a starter set:

  • 40 triangles
  • 24 squares
  • 12 pentagons

This allows construction of all five Platonic solids as well as a variety of Archimedean, Johnson, or other solids.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Individual pieces print quickly, so I recommend printing a large collection on a single plate. The hinges involve narrow protrusions and mild overhangs, so bed adhesion can be a problem; perhaps one time in four a plate will have a problem. Although other plastics are stronger, I find PLA is easy to print, feels nice, and is strong enough.

This object was designed in SpildPython, a python library that allows easy construction of OpenSCAD files. If you want to change any parameters, I strongly recommend going back to the Jupyter notebook I used to generate the objects.

title: 3s 18650 tripack endcap with integrated loop for zipties or velcro straps

description.text:
i had lots of salvaged 18650s left over and needed some 3s battery packs for my r/c planes, so i designed this triangular endcap to secure 3 18650 in series in a compact manner. it has an integrated loop, so you can fix it to whatever you need with velcro or zipties. my panasonic 18650s fit in just right, other brands might be a tad fatter so you should scale it up 1% just in case.
i recommend setting the caps in place with a flexible glue like sikaflex (or regular silicone) to protect your wires, balance leads, and your cells from shorting out due to water etc.

author: AHitler

description.text:
Updated on 14.11.2017 in order to fix some (..inexplicable) errors in cover_A.stl.
Updated on 28.08.2017 in order to fix some slightly misaligned holes and few other details.

This is a cover for the Arduino Mega + Ramps 1.4 control board, mounted on the CTC Prusa I3 printer (I replaced the original Geetech 2560 board that came with the printer).
There are two versions of the cover:

  • version A was designed to fit exactly the available holes on the side of my printer and covers pretty well the Arduino & Ramps shield;
  • version B is a more generic design and has symmetric screw holes;

The cover is also designed to accomodate a cooling fan in the middle (there are mounting holes set for 80mm, 70mm, 60mm, 50mm and 40mm diameter fans). I only actually used and tested it with an 80mm fan (as in the picture).

In any case, if you want to print this, first double check the dimensions with the attached schematic!

description.text:
THIS IS A WORK IN PROGRESS - THIS IS NOT A COMPLETE WORKING DESIGN

The last thing we need is another 3D printer. Sorry. My goal is to Keep It Simple, Stupid (KISS). As many printed parts as possible. Easy to source. Cheap.

One major departure from other printer is the belted Z. I just hate lead screws. One issue with a belted Z is that the bed tends to crash when motors lose power. I fixed that by using a worm gear I bought on AliExpress. I believe the weight of the bed will prevent any backlash. I'm using a 500mm long 5mm rod so I can use a single motor. Again, KISS.

I decided to go with 3 wheeled carriages because they are easy to adjust. My experience with lm8uu and bushings in general has been "interesting" so I decided not to use any and go with wheeled carriages exclusively. The bed is supported by carriages on all 4 corners. Obviously you will need a bunch of wheels, 21 to be exact. I paid less than $30 for all of them on AliExpress/Tevo and they were all fine.

All the extrusions except one are the same size (500mm). The biggest bed you can fit with a 500mm cube is probably 300x350mm and the Z print height is probably around 350mm.

I've included the STL of the latest versions of each part . I've also included the Fusion 360 files if you want to customize them, which you probably will have to do....

I don't have a formal BOM yet

* 8 Jan 2018
I added a generic mount for the Y and Z endstops as well as a X endstop mount for the X carriage with a little trigger that can be inserted in the XY Joiner's nut hole to trigger the endstop.

Printer:

Hypercube

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25% or better

Notes:

PETG or ABS would probably be best. That being said, I currently have a mix of PLA and PETG.
Some parts might have to be rotated to print without support. I will try to fix that in the final release.

description.text:
My new razor didn't come with a clip, so I designed one to fit on the edge of a glass shelf in the bathroom. It fits on the right-hand end of the shelf, but I've included a mirrored version for left-handers. The glass shelf had a 6mm gap to the wall so I included a block to stop it moving forward when the razor is removed. I've included versions without the block for people who have a shelf without a gap. The clip is made for an 8mm shelf, which seems to be more or less a standard.

It's printed in PETG, though I guess most materials would work. The clip was designed in Autodesk Inventor and I've added the files if someone wants to tweak it. The left-hand models are derived parts, so you'll need to edit the right-hand part to make changes.I cheated a bit by using fillets to create the curved surface, but that doesn't affect the integrity of the model. I haven't had a chance to test it with other models, but I made it a rather slack fit so iother designs should fit OK.

It's been in use for a couple of months without any issues.

title: Wanhao Duplicator 6 7" LCD holder for Octopi

description.text:
These are some brackets to allow you to attach an Official Raspberry Pi 7-inch touch screen and Raspberry Pi to the front of your Wanhao Duplicator 6 / Monoprice Maker Ultimate.

This is the screen/Raspi enclosure to use:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1585924

I also used this screen surround too (You don't have to, it was just my preference):
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2007689

You'll also need four M3x10 screws to bolt it all together.

I have the USB power for the Raspberry Pi running from a DC-DC step-down converter I installed inside the machine, connected to the 24v output on the main power supply.

I then ran the USB cable supplied with the printer through a hole in the corner of the machine, through the space at the bottom, then looped out the back and plugged into the USB port at the back.
There are clips integrated into the brackets for holding the USB cable neatly.

For the Ethernet connection, I just ran the cable under the machine and looped it up the front.
If you use Wi-Fi, you can do without the Ethernet wire, I just prefer a wired connection.

I've supplied STEP and Rhino 3D (.3dm) files so you can remix and stuff if needed. Just be cool and credit me somehow. :)

title: Drinker tray bottle caps for small birds
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Drinker trays for small birds, that would drown in deeper water. Water depth is around 5mm.

3 thread profiles available:

  • Pop / soda bottles (PCO-1810, ~28mm x 3.18mm)
  • Screw cap wine bottles (standard not found, measured as ~29mm x 3.5mm)
  • FlowFusor, a random bottle being thrown out by a local science shop (~35mm x 4.2mm)

The FlowFusor one is a bit bigger due to the size of the bottle, the pop and wine bottle ones are the same size.

Wine one has a W for identification, FlowFusor one has an F. Pop bottle one is unmarked as I figure it'll be the most commonly used one.

3 STL resolutions for each, pick your poison. Print in PLA for the sake of the birbs!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer, 0.4mm nozzle

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Make sure your zeroth layer clearance is nice and tight otherwise they won't be watertight!

3 perimeters to make the infill on the walls easier on your printer.

Print in PLA for the sake of the birbs.

description.text:
A box for holding Expo Markers (thin, pen/pencil style) 86601. This attaches to
a whiteboard with either suction cups, or a magnetic badge holder.

Bill of Materials

Expo Markers 86601

Attachment methods

Adams Manufacturing 7500-77-3040 1/8" Suction Cup

Use the suction cup without the hook, and press into the holes at the top. For
best success, clean surfaces before attaching. Use the pull tab to detach
and realign as necessary.

Badge magnets

Other badge magnets may work as long as they have 2mm of the magnet exposed. The
metal plate with adhesive backing should be kept for other purposes.

Press the magnetic part of the badge holder into the box, with the caution
symbols facing outward. Attach to a magnetic whiteboard/other magnetic surface.

description.text:
NOTE: Credit for the original 3d replica goes to Frederic
Original license: https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/
The current model is a remix of his work.

The original strange object was discovered in 1936 in Saqqara, Egypt. It is made of stone, is very thin and it has a very complicated shape that makes it look like some kind of machine part. The central axis seems to indicate it was spinning and part of a bigger machine or mechanism.

The object in the Cairo museum is about 61 centimeter in diameter and 10 cm in height. Nobody really knows who made it. We also don't know how, when or why was made. Mainstream science says it is at least 5000 years old, but he dynastic egyptians did not have the technology to do it. It is possibly made by an ancient high tech civilization existing thousands of years before the egyptian pharaos of 5000 years ago.

Video: Ancient Spinning Machine Part In The Cairo Museum Of Egypt

Website: The Mysterious Egyptian Tri-Lobed Disc

Video: Ancient Egyptian Tri Lobed Disc Oopart Artifact

Video: Lost Stone Cutting Technologies of Ancient Egypt - The Schist Disk

I have remixed the "Frederic model" by removing the central stick and provided a printable version with built-in support. The two stands (white in the pictures) are my designs. The current STL file is about or 145mm in diameter which is a bit less than 1/4 of the original object size (61 cm). As the model is very thin, a layer thickness of 0.15mm or less should be used when printing.

title: Anycubic Kossel/Delta replacement head body (+ retractable bed sensor mount)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
DISCLAIMER: This is currently being worked on. Parts are subject to modifications, and may require manual modifications to fit on printer.

So, here is my version of the Anycubic Kossel head body (I have the Linear Plus version), designed to include a retractable bed sensor.

It uses mostly the parts that comes with the printer, and does not modify the assembly. The additional parts needed is a 3010 fan (like these that comes with the chinese E3D j-head clones), a standard microswitch with the lever removed, and a RC micro servo (using MG90s, but SG90 should be fine).
I strongly suggest to replace the M3x8 screws that fix the body over the effector with M3x12 (M3x15 may fit too).

Head fan has been replaced to make room for the sensor mecanism. For now, the hole for fixing the servo have to be hand drilled, or the servo glued to the body.

I'm currently working on finding the right solution for the retractation, suggestions are welcome.

*** UPDATE 10/10/2017

Removed the 3Dprinted slider, it was hard to assemble and unaccurate.

Added a version with BLTouch mount. Sensor is at 0mm, -25.5mm (relative to nozzle).
PLEASE NOTE: you must modify the original effector for this version, grinding/drilling about 6mm in the effector at opposite side of the radial fan.
Feel free to contact me for any other Z height, this one is what fits my printer, but you may have a slightly different head requiring Z height adjustment.

Printer:

OpenEdge HD2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

better aligned to 1mm / 0.20 or 0.25

Infill:

low to medium

Notes:

Parts are designed to print without support.

Parts orientation should not be changed.

The sensor slider have a quite long bridge that have no functional use, if the bridge does not print well, just sand/cut it away.

1. Fix the radial fan on the body.
  2. Place the j-head in the body.
  3. Fix the body on the effector.
  4. Fix the servo on the body.
  5. Insert the bed sensor, make it slide by hand and sand if needed.
  6. Remove the bed sensor and assemble it.
  7. Re-insert the bed sensor.
  8. Wire, configure, enjoy.

description.text:
Video of it being used to steer a rc "rover".

This little thing will let you create differential steering on two brushed dc motors using the output of a 9g servo. I needed this for a rc tank which in other cases needs fancy electronics or arduino programming to create the steering effect.

CARBON BRUSH VERSION ADDED(cheap ones from ebay) since I've had problems with the wire that was used before. If you are using wire as the brush, make sure it has good contact with the rail aka push it through the spinnie holder thing quite a bit.

I recommend using the carbon brush version since it has been more reliable for me. Things to note is that there seams to be alot of ressistance in the brushes. The motors run at the same rpm as before but now on a 3s versus the previous 2s.

UPDATE WAITING TO HAPPEN. I need to redesign how the housing for the carbon brushes attaches to the servo. It is currently attached as if the housing was a servo horn but this has failed for me. I need to make so that the servo has a already existing premade horn attached and the housing then attaches onto that. Sorry for the delays of updates, i will work on it once I have time.

If you have any upgrades of your own please post it <3

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed using PLA with support where needed.

Materials: 4mm copper tube (for the rails):
http://www.ebay.com/itm/2M-Soft-Microbore-Copper-Tube-Pipe-OD-4mm-x-ID-3mm-For-Refrigeration-Plumbing-/182377790443?epid=581859385&hash=item2a76903beb:g:9K4AAOSwImRYRQ~C Cheap generic 9g servo from ebay:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/SG90-9G-Micro-Servo-Motor-RC-Robot-Arm-Helicopter-Airplane-Remote-Control-/291982950142?var=&hash=item43fb8a3efe:m:mru4XIW6Unw42zEMrikxjyQ ca 10awg/3mm diameter aluminum wire (wire brushes):
http://www.ebay.com/itm/12-AWG-10-Feet-Gauge-Silicone-Wire-Flexible-Stranded-Cables-for-RC-Black-Red-ED-/112138929314?epid=1373853081&hash=item1a1c0044a2:g:fcoAAOSwiONYQDBK 15 10 6mm carbon brushes (carbon brushes):
https://www.ebay.com/itm/20-pcs-power-tool-repair-15mm-x-10mm-x-6mm-motor-carbon-brushes/182546713180?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649 +solder
+connector of choise
+heatshrink
+small screws (left over servo attachment screws work great)
+hot glue

Assembley:

WHEN USING WIRES AS BRUSHES:

  1. Cut and bend two pieces of copper tube that fit into the grooves on the base.
  2. Attach a wire to each of the copper tube so that it sticks out through the premade hole inside the grooves on the base.
  3. Push the copper tube into the groove while keeping the wire sticking out.
  4. Attach the servo underneath the base using two screws.
  5. Cut four pieces of wire about 15cm/6" long and strip off about 4mm/0,15" on one of the ends. This will end up being the brush.
  6. Push one wire at a time through the correct hole in the servo arm so that it sticks out by around 6mm/0,2", just enough so that the stripped part of the wire is sticking out. Glue the wire into place with hotglue from the back. Make sure the gluegun isn't too hot so that it warps the plastic.
  7. Finish it up by pushing the four servo wires through the top of the top and screw the top on. Add a ziptie around the four top wires to releave stress from pulling.

WHEN USING CARBON BRUSHES:
Same as before for most part, but instead of adding wires for the brushes you change some stuff.

  1. First solder the cables (previously their ends were brushes) onto the metal parts on the carbon brushes.
  2. Push in the carbon brushes until they get nice and snug in the hole. They should move freely where they are poking out.
  3. Glue the metal tops of the brushes on the top so they wont come out.
  4. Push the whole servo spinny thing onto the servo holder thing so that is aligns according the the drawing above. (+ to + etc)
  5. You're done :)

I would really appreciate if someone improved this design or made a proposal for a better solution.

(I am aware of how much better this can be done using electronics but I have not been able to find something simple and affordable that uses a servo connector)

remixed_from.author: piercet
remixed_from.title: Inner Y Rail specific Y Motor Mount for NEMA 17 Motors

title: Bearing support for use with Inner Y rail mount

description.text: I like a lot of tension on my Y belt, and I was worried that only having one side of the NEMA motor shaft supported could cause damage over time. So, this is an attempt at reinforcing that shaft by adding a bearing on the other side. This requires a single 605ZZ 5x14x5 5mm/14mm/5mm 605Z Miniature Ball Deep Groove Radial Ball Bearings, though you can add two of them if you have a particularily long motor shaft.

Print it out, and stick the bearing in place. If you have a particularily short shaft, you may need to trim either the motor mount or the back of the support itself slightly for clearance. This will only work with the allignment of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:221557 as far as I know.

author: piercet

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
This a camera slider I designed to be GoPro mount compatible to assist me in creating better footage for videos. The system can be driven by pushing the platform, turning the crank handle, or via a cordless drill. I designed this slider with two thoughts in mind. I want it to be inexpensive to build and allow for multiple ways to drive the system. Originally, I intended to have three drive systems; hand driven, drill driven and to motorize it. I'm still working on motorizing it, but with the original idea of keeping the design cheap so that anyone could build it with minimal impact on their wallet.

Please feel free to remix/modify to your needs. I did test it out with the weight of a DSLR camera and it worked absolutely fine however I haven't finished the platform to mount a regular camera yet. Not difficult to do, I've just been working on other things. I do plan on improving the design as needed, so don't hesitate to leave comments/suggestions.

Update 10/01/17: Added the F3D file so others can remix if they so choose.

author: KillerSmurfling

description.text:
Hi

This is a cool little Box i designed, based on a Rhombenikosidodekaeder. It has a thick bottom, so it won't roll around too easy. I printed it slightly above my average infill, so there is just a little more mass down there. The first row is a bit tough because of the overhang, but even my not so god Anet A8 and a pretty cheap PLA managed to get it alright. I personally didn't use support. And of course you can always sand it to make it look perfect, the walls are thick enough. The whole thing is actually pretty rigid. You can print it at pretty much every size.

Designing this was actually quite a pain :D I used wikipedia to get the angles and then the 3D sketch tool from Fusion 360, drew every surface on its own and then extruded every single one, it just wouldn't let me do it any other way.

description.text:
My first version of a standard 12 inch (33 1/3 RPM) record weight (and/or stabilizer). Since I didn't see any designs I thought I'd make my own.

Record Weights are believed to help reduce external vibrations from speakers, help flatten warped records, and of course, adds a little eye candy to your rig!

All printers print slightly different so use the "penny tester" STL to make sure the scaling % is right to make pennies fit before printing everything.

SPECS:
-6 internal compartments to add US pennies to create desired weight. Recommend using a scale to find your preferred weight.

-Spindle hole is sized slightly larger than my spindle just to make sure it fits all turntables.

-Outer diameter is sized to add clearance for most of the larger style needles when vinyl has ended (see photo).

-The weight height should fit in most turntables with the dust lid closed. If its too tall (or too short), simply change the Z scaling %.

RECOMMENDATIONS:
-Print walls 2 layers thick and have supports enabled for under the lid. Sized for a smooth print with a 0.4mm nozzle.

-Add rubber or felt to the bottom of the weight to keep it from scratching your vinyl label.

This is the first version, and I'm open for suggestions. Thinking about making it fit 45 RPM vinyls in the future.

Thanks! And Print On!

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

0.1-0.2mm

Infill:

20-30%

comments.text: Very cool!  How much weight do all of the pennies add?  Have you noticed any difference when using it at all on albums which are slightly warped?
comments.author: Sixstring78

comments.text: Thanks! I think I got it up to almost 300 grams with it full of pennies. Don't weigh it down too much since it puts more stain on cheaper turntable motors. I did try it on one of my warped vinyls (so bad it would skip) and while it didn't fix it completely I did notice at least the skipping stopped with the weight on. Hope this helps!
comments.author: Sixstring78

comments.text: That’s good to hear that it was heavy enough to stop the skipping. I have a SL-1200MK2 so I’m not worried about the extra weight on the platter. I’m definitely going to try printing this.

description.text:
As the title suggests, I rounded over the edges of these parts. The goals were to simply eliminate the sharp edges and to enhance the appearance a bit. (subjective) I also strengthened the mounting holes on the LCD mount. Two of mine broke off really easily on the original design while removing it from the print bed. I have printed most of these parts and like the way they have turned out. Enjoy.

UPDATE: 31 Dec 2017 Added "strengthened" Y rail mounts. One of mine cracked...

comments.text: Thanks!  Going to start printing/building my AM8 later this week, and intend to print these parts instead of the base parts.  Any tips for infill % or orientation issues you've run into?
comments.author: snowveil

comments.text: Hey... I printed everything at 50% infill and the tensioner at 100%. The only issue I had was one of the LCD cover corners melted a little. Not sure if my bed has hot spots or the part sitting on it for four hours caused it. For the larger parts I now lower the bed temp from 60 to 55 or even 50C. I print on glass and have no adhesion issues so your mileage may vary. Good luck and please post images.

print_settings.Notes:: 3 shells, PETG or PLA plus, you will need supports, print with the diiicooler bracket facing vertically up. You will need qty 2 m4 nuts for the bearing holders to attach to and qty 2 m2 nuts for the x stop to attach to, all other hardware is stock.

title: Wanhao I3 Plus/Maker Select Plus Titan Aero mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is highly experimental and requires making custom cables and modification of the stock wiring harness. I take no responsibility if you cook your machine doing this. Still under testing, I have about 500 hours on mine between a few revisions of the design. Works with DiiiCooler, uses the e3d standard (not mirrored) titan aero, with slight reduction in build area. How much is still being determined.

This replaces the entire metal bracket that the direct drive attaches to, reducing weight. new adjustable end stops are required and it may or may not work with a cobra cooler, I don't have one to test but the bearing holder bottom holes are kept free to allow for its use.

Photos are of a prior version, the current version has a space on top for a zip tie to hold the wires in place.

Additional parts required to be printed:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1394558 qty 1
https://www.thingiverse.com/download:3442143 qty 2 Note: the stops linked are for the 2.1, not the plus, which has a different mount for the y stop, thus the 2 z stops. Just trust me.

Printer:

Maker Select Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

90

Notes:

3 shells, PETG or PLA plus, you will need supports, print with the diiicooler bracket facing vertically up. You will need qty 2 m4 nuts for the bearing holders to attach to and qty 2 m2 nuts for the x stop to attach to, all other hardware is stock.

The heater wires, fan wires and thermistor wires are custom length and terminated in a 2 pin JST-XHP connector. The motor direction needs to be reversed, either with custom firmware or reversing the pins, then the steps need to be updated for the geared extruder with M92. Steps depends on if you are using a .9 or 1.8 stepper.
